comment: If you're even 1 second late on the deadline give up, he's not going to accept any excuses. People rated him well so I think he just seems more aloof online. Its reading heavy and I didn't like that, it was boring. I also did an extra credit opportunity for 15 points and he didn't grade it. If he did, I would have actually passed the class.

The class was relatively easy, and the lectures while long, were interesting. However, lectures were not what we were tested on so make sure to do your readings, but genuinely as long as you show up and do your work, you'll be fine. Be careful of the briefs, try not to procrastinate (I know you will anyways tho)

Professor Shepherd is a pretty decent professor. He's passionate and knowledgeable, and it will be to your benefit. My biggest gripe is that 80% of our tests were from the textbook and not gone over in class- his tests were long and tedious, and there was really only 3 exams and 2 papers, but I just prefer to be taught in class. Good extra credit.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Graded by few things

comment: All of the tests were online which puts a huge weight off my shoulders, the assignments are ridiculously easy and the only thing that brought my grade down was the two briefs.

I really enjoyed this professor, he's definitely passionate about Pols while also understanding this is a gen ed class. Hard tests that has questions that are not explicitly covered in class, but they are open book online. Lots of extra credit opportunities.

The class is really easy and the format is very predictable. My largest complaint is that he takes until the end of the semester to put your grades in for the Written Assignments (which you have four of), and other grades also come in really slow. He's also not immensely helpful via email. Not hard at all, though. I'd take this class again.

His grades consisted of weekly quizzes (which don't require a lockdown browser or webcam) and either an essay or discussion post. He offers extra credit opportunities and there are no tests or finals! The only issue would be how long it takes him to grade the essays and make sure you meet his requirements.

One week would be a discussion post and a quiz and the next week would be an essay for the whole semester. No tests though and quiz's are not lockdown. Material was actually quite easy and you don't need to purchase a textbook. He is kind of a tough grader on essays but overall not a bad class. This professor is probably your best bet for POLS.

The class definitely isn't a cake walk, but he's pretty fair with his grading. Work alternates almost every week (one week was back to back essays) from a quiz and discussion posts to an essay, so don't take him if you hate essays. You'll be fine as long as you answer the prompt, but the quizzes are rough if you don't read the textbook
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: There are a lot of writing assignments and lengthy discussion posts, but overall, I think he's a great professor. The class was asynchronous, but the syllabus tells you when everything is due, you just have to make sure that you keep up with it.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--So many papers

comment:
Mr. Shepherd was a great professor. He's very fair and straightforward with his students, and manages to make a traditionally boring class very engaging and interesting. 
Personally I think he did a phenomenal job and he got me interested in politics which is not something I ever cared about before. 
10/10 guy.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: I initially didn't have plans to write a review for Professor Shepherd, but someone considering his class told me about what was written about him. Most of the bad reviews on here didn't even fill out the details on the class, so they probably just wanted to defame the professor. He is very respectful to students, knowledgable and fair.

The bulk of grade comes from 3 tests and 2 briefs. The briefs are very easy, just follow the rubric. If it asks "What is the importance of the New Jersey plan?", literally answer word for word, "New Jersey Plan is important because etc." The tests are taken at home, they are all multiple choice, he k we google the answers but dont care

He was very clear about how he would grade for the semester. Most of the questions on the tests came from the textbook. The rest came from the lectures and guest speakers. He offers ways to get extra credit. This class can be hard if you do not have previous knowledge about the political government. His tests were +100 questions.

The professor is super nice went to a couple lectures up until the first test and simple struggled and decided to withdraw but I do work so I guess I should've chose wisely. You are graded by a point system and are given extra credit opportunities but there's only about 3 tests so there's not much to work with.

Very good professor! His guest speakers are awesome! Decently interesting lectures, but 1hr:30 of him definitely gets old quick. Tests are 80/20 textbook/lecture. Fairly specific textbook Q's. No lockdown browser. 2 500w papers. Expect to spend 30-45m on notes/day. When referring to political parties, his lectures are always fair to both sides.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Caring
